content.webTitle: Championship roundup: Malky Mackay urges Wigan to keep fighting

fields.headline: Championship roundup: Malky Mackay urges Wigan to keep fighting
fields.bodyText: Blackpool 1-3 Wigan Athletic Malky Mackay challenged his Wigan side to keep putting pressure on their fellow strugglers after a vital 3-1 win at bottom side Blackpool. “It’s a great result,” said Mackay, whose side remain second-bottom, nine points adrift of Rotherham. “It was always going to be a tough one: there’s a fighting spirit at Blackpool, it’s a local derby and the pitch is quite something right now. For anybody to be calm and play football the way they did, I take my hat off.” Blackpool manager Lee Clark said: “It’s tough. But while it’s mathematically possible we’ve got to keep going.” Cardiff City 0-1 Wolverhampton Wanderers Kenny Jackett said he is daring to dream of automatic promotion after Bakary Sako’s goal gave the visitors three crucial points at Cardiff, spoiling Vincent Tan’s first visit of the season. The Malaysian owner had not watched his team live since May, but saw them beaten, with their cause not helped by a second-half red card for Peter Whittingham. “We have goals and spirit,” said Jackett. “It’s still there for us. You have to believe we can do it.” Russell Slade said: “The owner spoke to the players before the game and I’ve spoken to him since. He thought we were unlucky.” Rotherham United 2-1 Millwall Ian Holloway admitted feeling the pressure after Millwall’s fans turned on him – and were involved in clashes with police. Trouble began after Kari Arnason’s 85th-minute winner, with reports of more violence outside the ground after full-time. “I didn’t see [the fighting],” said Holloway. “I was concentrating on my job and I felt I acted with dignity from start to finish. I’m not getting results so the fans turn on me – but I’m glad they’re doing that rather than getting at the team. I believe I can turn this around, but if other people don’t then it’s not in my control.” And the rest Ten-man Birmingham secured three points and set back Brentford’s play-off hopes with James Tarkowski’s own goal giving them a 1-0 win at St Andrew’s. ■ Bolton’s Zach Clough scored his sixth goal in nine games, earning a 1-0 win that leaves Brighton six points off the relegation zone. ■ Bournemouth are without a win in five after being held to a scrappy 0-0 home draw by Blackburn – a match delayed by half an hour after a road accident left Artur Boruc and Tommy Elphick stuck in traffic. ■ Tony Watt scored twice as Charlton beat former manager Chris Powell’s Huddersfield side 3-0 at The Valley. ■ Reading went down 3-0 at home to Dougie Freedman’s resurgent Nottingham Forest side with Ben Osborn, Matty Fryatt and Gary Gardner scoring the goals. ■ And Sheffield Wednesday achieved their first home win since Boxing Day, 2-0 against second-placed Middlesbrough.
